revision.text:
There have been a number of '''religious controversies''' over the [[teaching of science]], certain [[religious practice]]s, and in the [[depiction of religion]] or [[depiction of religious figures (disambiguation)|religious figures]] in culture.
:''Main articles: [[Religion]] and [[Controversy]]'' ==Science and religion== {{main|Creation-evolution controversy}} The greatest contemporary controversy involving religion and science is the teaching of [[evolution]] in schools{{Fact|date=March 2009}}. This debate is most prevalent in generally conservative regions of the United States and there is little serious debate on the subject outside the United States.
==Society== The [[Chinese Rites controversy]] was a dispute within the Catholic Church from the 1630s to the early 18th century about whether Chinese folk religion rites and offerings to the emperor constituted idolatry or not.
[[Female genital cutting]] and [[circumcision]] attract controversy especially when practiced outside of the countries in which they are commonly performed.
==Art, literature and popular culture== ===Visual arts=== *The controversial photographic exhibition [[Ecce Homo (exhibition)|Ecce Homo]] *[[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy]] *[[Piss Christ]], a photo taken by American photographer [[Andres Serrano]] of [[Jesus Christ]] in a glass of the photographer's urine *[[Strelnikoff Mary of Help of Brezje controversy]] *[[Chris Ofili]] and his [[The Holy Virgin Mary|Sacred Virgin Mary]] montage *Tania Kovats' ''[[Virgin in a Condom]]'' attracted protests at the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]]. *Stanislav Shmulevich was facing hate crime charges for dumping a possibly-stolen Qur'an into a public toilet and publishing a photo of it in 2007<ref>[http://chronicle.com/news/article/2761/student-arrested-in-koran-in-toilet-incidents-at-pace-u Student Arrested in Koran-in-Toilet Incidents at Pace U. - Chronicle.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://michellemalkin.com/2007/07/30/which-of-these-is-a-crime-in-america/ Michelle Malkin » Which of these is a crime in America? Update: Criminal complaint added<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He later plead guilty to disorderly conduct and must perform 300 hours of community service.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/pace-university-student-dumped-qurans-toilet-community-service-article-1.285011 Pace University student who dumped Qurans in toilet gets community service]</ref> *Anonymous artwork of a nude woman on a [[prayer rug]] on display at [[OCAD University]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nationalpost.com/opinion/christie-blatchford-depiction-of-nude-on-a-prayer-mat-too-provocative-for-ontario-art-school |first=Christie |last=Blatchford |date=March 6, 2018 |publisher=''[[The National Post]]'' |title=Christie Blatchford: Depiction of nude on a prayer mat too provocative for Ontario art school |archive-date=March 7, 2018 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20180307035016/http://nationalpost.com/opinion/christie-blatchford-depiction-of-nude-on-a-prayer-mat-too-provocative-for-ontario-art-school |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Books=== *''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'' has had many complaints centered on the book's speculations and alleged misrepresentations of core aspects of Christianity and the history of the Roman Catholic Church. (see ''[[Criticisms of The Da Vinci Code]]'') * There is controversy surrounding [[Salman Rushdie]]'s novel ''[[The Satanic Verses]]'' and the author was threatened with death. (''see [[The Satanic Verses controversy]]'') *''[[Lajja]]'', a novel by [[Taslima Nasrin]] which led to protests and death threats in Bangladesh and the author having to flee the country *''[[His Dark Materials]]'' is a trilogy of fantasy novels by Philip Pullman that has attracted criticism from some religious individuals and groups due to the negative portrayal of organised religion. *[[Religious debates over the Harry Potter series|Religious debates over the ''Harry Potter'' book series]] by J. K. Rowling stem largely from assertions that the Harry Potter novels contain occult or Satanic subtext.
===Film/Television=== *''[[Monty Python's Life of Brian]]'', a controversial comedy film about religion, attracted controversy and was censored in some British towns, such as Aberystwyth in [[Wales]] for almost 30 years after it was first released. *[[South Park]]'s controversial [[Bloody Mary (South Park)|''Bloody Mary'' episode]]. *[[The Last Temptation of Christ (film)|''The Last Temptation of Christ'']] film, as with the novel of the same name, depicts the life of Jesus Christ while free from sin, was still subject to every form of temptation that humans face, including fear, doubt, depression, reluctance and lust. *[[Innocence of Muslims]], a low-budget film that ridicules Islam and its prophet, [[Muhammad]], and as a result, it causes furor in the Muslim world including the [[2012 diplomatic missions attacks]].
==See also== *[[Censorship by religion]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Religious controversies| ]] [[Category:Lists of controversies]]

revision.text:
{{Serer religion}} {{Serer titles}} '''Saltigue''', sometimes spelt ''Saltigué'' or wrongly ''Saltigui'', are [[Serer people|Serer]] high priests and priestesses who preside over the religious ceremonies and affairs of the Serer people, such as the ''Xoy'' ceremony, the biggest event in the Serer religious calendar. They usually come from ancient Serer paternal families. Such a title is usually inherited by birthright.<ref>Henri Gravrand. La Civilisation Seereer. Pangool. Published by Les Nouvelles Edition Africaines du Senegal (1990). {{ISBN|2-7236-1055-1}}</ref><ref>Kalis, Simone, "Medecine Traditionnele Religion et Divination Chez Les Seereer Siin du Senegal", L'Harmattan (1997), pp 11–297, {{ISBN|2-7384-5196-9}}</ref> The term ''"Saltigi"'' is also adopted by the [[Fula people]]. They were the leaders of the Fulas in some Fula areas, belonging to the [[Denianke Dynasty]] of the [[Empire of Great Fulo]] founded by Koli Tengella Bâ in the 16th century.<ref>M. Th. Houtsma. E. J. Brill's first encyclopaedia of Islam 1913–1936. BRILL. {{ISBN|90-04-08265-4}}. p 663</ref> It is proposed that the word "''Saltigi''", used in reference to the Fulas, comes from the [[Mandinka language]], in which it means ''"master of the road"'', used in reference to their neighbors who are Fulani herders and tenders of the flock, the traditional activity of Fulani leaders.<ref>[[Godfrey Mwakikagile|Mwakikagile, Godfrey]], ''Ethnic Diversity and Integration in the [[Gambia]]:'' The Land, the People and the Culture. {{ISBN|9987-9322-2-3}}. p163</ref> In Serer country, ''Saltigue'', not to be confused with ''Saltigi'', are always [[Divination|diviners]]. In [[Wolof people|Wolof]] areas, they were the assistant chiefs.<ref>Klein, Martin A., ''Islam and Imperialism in [[Senegal]] [[Sine-Saloum]], 1847–1914'', Edinburgh University Press (1968) p 262</ref> The scope of this article deals only with ''Saltigue'' or ''Saltigué'' – "diviners" (the high priests and priestesses) and termed by some scholars as "the ministers of the religious cult";<ref>University of Texas at Austin. African and Afro-American Studies and Research Center, University of Texas at Austin. African and Afro-American Research Institute, African Studies Association. African Literature Committee, Modern Language Association of America. African Literatures Seminar, African Literature Association, Modern Language Association of America. African Literatures Division. "Research in African literatures, Volume 24". African and Afro-American Studies and Research Center, University of Texas [at Austin], 1993. p 97</ref> ''"[[pastor]]s of the people"''<ref>[[Marcel Mahawa Diouf|Diouf, Marcel Mahawa]], ''Lances mâles: [[Léopold Sédar Senghor]] et les traditions Sérères'', Centre d'études linguistiques et historiques par tradition orale, 1996. The University of Michigan. p 14</ref> or within the remits of these definitions.
==Role of Saltigues== The Saltigues were advisers to Serer governments, for example in the old Serer Kingdoms of [[Kingdom of Sine|Sine]], [[Saloum]] and [[Baol]]. Their principal role was and still is for the prosperity of the country. In this role, they were responsible for predicting the future of kings; the weather to come (for the purposes of agriculture); any natural disaster or political catastrophe that could befall the country; etc. As such, they were frequently consulted by the Serer kings ([[Maad a Sinig]] and [[Maad Saloum]])<ref>In the [[Serer language]], ''Maad'' and very rarely used ''Maat'' (though correct) means "king" i.e. [[Maad a Sinig]] (King of [[Kingdom of Sine|Sine]]), [[Maad Saloum]] (King of [[Saloum]]). The [[Lamane]]s, – the ancient Serer kings and [[landed gentry]], should not be confused with the post-[[Guelowar]] Lamanes who were merely the landed gentry and provincial chiefs answerable to the king. There are two types of Lamanes in Serer chronology : Lamanes pre-Guelowar (the original Lamanes, kings and landowners) and Lamanes during and after the Guelowar period (1350–1969) (mere chiefs and landowners)</ref> preferably at the beginning of the rainy season.<ref>[[Alioune Sarr|Sarr, Alioune]], ''Histoire du Sine-Saloum'', Introduction, bibliographie et notes par Charles Becker, BIFAN, Tome 46, Serie B, n° 3–4, 1986–1987. p31</ref>
Before a king launches a war against another kingdom, or to repel an attack from another kingdom, the king consults the great assembly of Saltigues to predict the outcome of the battle, as was the case of Saltigué and ''Diaraf'' Wassaly Sene and Saltigué Laba Diene Ngom at the [[Battle of Fandane-Thiouthioune]] (18 July 1867), commonly known as the Battle of Somb, during the reign of [[Maad a Sinig Kumba Ndoffene Famak Joof]].<ref>Sarr, Alioune . Histoire du [[Sine-Saloum]]. Introduction, bibliographie et notes par Charles Becker, BIFAN, Tome 46, Serie B, n° 3–4, 1986–1987. pp 31–38</ref><ref>Diouf, Mahawa, ''L'information Historique: L'exemple du Siin.'' Ethiopiques n°54 revue semestrielle de culture négro-africaine. Nouvelle série volume 7 2e semestre 1991</ref><ref>Diouf, Niokhobaye, ''Chronique du Royaume du Sine'', IFAN, commenté par Charles Becker & Victor Martin (1972)</ref><ref>Klein, Martin A., ''Islam and Imperialism in Senegal Sine-Saloum, 1847–1914.'' [[Edinburgh University Press]] (1968), p 91</ref> The assembly of Saltigues will predict the outcome, offer precautionary advice on when to launch the attack, the route to take to the battlefield and the animals to be sacrificed, etc. The role of Saltigue was not political. They are not government ministers or politicians, but spiritual advisors and elders. They are the Serer hereditary "Rain priests" – guardians of the [[Serer religion]] and customs, a birthright they inherited from their ancient [[Lamane|Lamanic]] ancestors.<ref>Sarr, Alioune,, ''Histoire du Sine-Saloum'', Introduction, bibliographie et notes par Charles Becker, BIFAN, Tome 46, Serie B, n° 3–4, 1986–1987. p31</ref>
In the [[precolonialism|precolonial]] period, during the ''Raan Festival''<ref>See [[Serer religion]] for Raan Festival.</ref> which takes place in [[Tukar]] annually on the second Thursday after the onset of the [[new moon]] in April, the kings (during the [[Guelowar]] period<ref>In Serer history and chronology, the Guelowar period starts from 1350 during the reign of [[Maad a Sinig Maysa Wali Jaxateh Manneh]] – the first Guelowar king to reign in Serer country i.e. the [[Kingdom of Sine]] and ends in 1969 following the deaths of [[Maad a Sinig Mahecor Joof]] and [[Maad Saloum]] Fode N'Goye Joof, king of Sine and [[Saloum]] respectively.</ref>) will attend the Raan Festival of Tukar, making their way from the capital ([[Diakhao Arrondissement|Diakhao]]). However, the king was extremely careful never to arrive before the Lamane<ref>These should not be confused with pre-Guelowar Lamanes, who were the kings and landowners (the [[landed gentry]] among the old the Serer noble classes).</ref> and always avoid direct encounters with the Lamane of Tukar. Whilst the Lamane was busy self-meditating, touring Tukar and making offerings to the [[pangool]] Jegan Joof, the Chief Saltigue and his associates drink ''sum-sum'' alcohol all morning before the Festival. It is reported that drinking ''sum-sum'' improves the Saltigue's vision of the future and the supernatural world.
Having prepared himself sufficiently, the Saltigue and his close associates leave the house and mount their horses, then start their own tour of some of the sacred places of the country. The Saltigué's tour is programmed to follow the king, but ultimately to cross his path at a location known as 'Nenem". In this location, the king, aware that the Saltigue is coming, stops the royal entourage. The king and the royal entourage must wait for the Saltigue and his companions to pass. After these high priests and priestesses have passed, the king then gives the signal to the royal entourage to pass as they proceed to their next destination. This is the kind of respect that is afforded to the Saltigue.<ref>Galvan, Dennis Charles, ''The State Must Be Our Master of Fire:'' How Peasants Craft Culturally Sustainable Development in Senegal. Berkeley, University of California Press ( 2004). pp 202–204</ref> Scholars like [[Alioune Sarr]] note that Saltigues are famously celebrated and respected in Serer Kingdoms because of their knowledge.<ref>Sarr, Alioune, ''Histoire du Sine-Saloum'', Introduction, bibliographie et notes par Charles Becker, BIFAN, Tome 46, Serie B, n° 3–4, 1986–1987. p31</ref>
==Serer and Lebu healing methods== The [[Lebu people]] share many cosmo-spiritual beliefs with the [[Serer people|Serers]]. Many Lebu ''rab'' ([[jinn]]) are actually Serer ''[[pangool]]'' ([[Reincarnation#Serer religion|ancestral spirits or saints]]). The sacred dwelling place of the Lebu ''rab'' is the same as the Serer ''pangool'' called ''Sangomar'', based on the ancient Serer and [[Diola people|Diola]] legend of ''[[The legend of Jambooñ and Agaire|Jambooñ and Agaire]]''.<ref>Many variations of spelling especially Agaire. Sometimes spelt Ageen, Ougeney, Eugene, etc. Jambooñ is sometimes spelt Jambon, Jambonge, etc. Fata Ndiaye in Ethiopiques {{fr}} [http://ethiopiques.refer.sn/spip.php?article1245 Le SIIN avant les Gelwaar]</ref> – two young sisters whose boat split into half around [[the Point of Sangomar]]. One sails to the north, the other sails south. Those traveling south became the ancestors of the Diolas and the other became the ancestor of the Serers. The healing method of the Lebu is called ''ndepp'' while the Serer healing method is called ''Loup''.<ref>[http://www.abibitumikasa.com/yabb/Attachments/coumbalambafinalreport.pdf The Cosaan Foundation]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>Ecole pratique des hautes études (France). 6. section: Sciences économiques et sociales. Cahiers d'études africaines, Volume 46, Issues 181–184. Mouton (2006). p 922</ref><ref>Schwarz-Bart, Simone & Schwarz-Bart, André,'' In Praise of Black Women: Modern African women,'' Translated by: Rose-Myriam Réjouis, Val Vinokurov. Univ of Wisconsin Press, 2003. {{ISBN|0-299-17270-8}}. p62.</ref><ref>Taal, Ebou Momar, ''Senegambian Ethnic Groups:'' Common Origins and Cultural Affinities Factors and Forces of National Unity, Peace and Stability. 2010</ref><ref>Wright, Donald R, ''Oral Traditions from the Gambia: Family elders.'' Ohio University Center for International Studies, Africa Program, 1979. {{ISBN|0-89680-084-9}}. pp 48–189</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Serer religion|Serer people|Senegal|Gambia|Traditional African religion|Religion|Africa|Mauritania}}
* [[Serer religion]] * [[Roog]] * [[Serer people]] * [[Lebu people]] * [[Serer prehistory]] * [[Hogon]]

{{Use dmy dates|date = February 2012}} {{Infobox Political party |country = Cambodia |name = Khmer Unity Party
Sangkum Jatiniyum Front Party |logo = SJFP.jpg |logo_size = 200px |colorcode = orange |leader = [[Khieu Rada]] |foundation = 23 October 1997 [http://flagspot.net/flags/kh-polit.html#kup] |ideology = [[Liberalism]]
[[Liberal democracy]]
[[Nationalism]] |website = [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://kup.free.fr/ http://kup.free.fr/] |seats1_title = [[National Assembly of Cambodia|National Assembly]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|123|hex=pink}} |seats2_title = [[Senate of Cambodia|Senate]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|58|hex=pink}} }} The Alliance of the National Community (''Sangkum Cheat Niyum'') that represented four parties had all of its four parties merge and be transformed into a political party called the '''Sangkum Jatiniyum Front Party''' and one of them is the Khmer Unity Party.{{cite web |url=http://www.camnet.com.kh/cambodia.daily/story_month/March-10-07.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023203706/http://www.camnet.com.kh/cambodia.daily/story_month/March-10-07.htm |archivedate=23 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}[http://ki-media.blogspot.com/2006/07/thomico-announces-alliance-with-fringe.html] The '''Khmer Unity Party''', is a [[Cambodia]]n opposition party founded in 1997 by its actual president [[Khieu Rada]], who was previously part of the royalist [[FUNCINPEC]] party. It declares itself a "liberal, democratic and nationalist" party.[http://flagspot.net/flags/kh-polit.html#kup] ==SJFP KUP image gallery== Image:2003-07-Flyer.jpg|Logo Image:RoyalistonhorseSJFP-logo.jpg|Royal rider Image:SJFP-logo.jpg|2nd Royalist on horse logo ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://sjfparty.free.fr/ sjfparty.free.fr] {{Cambodian political parties}} [[Category:1997 establishments in Cambodia]] [[Category:Buddhist political parties]] [[Category:Cambodian democracy movements]] [[Category:Liberal parties in Cambodia]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in Cambodia]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1997]] [[Category:Political parties in Cambodia]] {{Cambodia-party-stub}}

The '''Santa Barbara Pastoral Region''' is a pastoral region of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles|Archdiocese of Los Angeles]] in the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. It covers [[Santa Barbara County, California|Santa Barbara]] and [[Ventura County, California|Ventura]] counties in the state of [[California]], [[United States|USA]]. The region has 37 parishes, 6 high schools, 18 elementary schools, 4 hospitals, and 4 [[Spanish missions in California|Spanish Missions]]. The current Episcopal Vicar for the region is Bishop [[Robert Barron (bishop)|Robert E. Barron]].
==Parishes==
===Deanery I (Lompoc, Solvang, Santa Maria)=== [[Image:Mission StInes.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Mission Santa Ines]] * Immaculate Conception, 4793 Cebrian. [[New Cuyama, California|New Cuyama]], CA 93254 * [[Mission La Purisima Concepcion|La Purisima Concepcion]], 213 West Olive Avenue, Lompoc, CA 93436 * [[Mission Santa Ines|Old Mission Santa Ines]], 1760 Mission Drive, Solvang, CA 93463 * Our Lady of Guadalupe, 1164 Obispo Street, Guadalupe, CA 93434 * Queen of Angels, 3495 Rucker Road, Lompoc, CA 93436 * [http://www.stneumann.com/ St. John Neumann], 966 West Orchard Street, Santa Maria, CA 93458 * [https://sldm.org/ St. Louis de Montfort], 5075 Harp Road, Santa Maria, CA 93455 * [http://www.stmary-sm.org/ St. Mary of the Assumption], 414 East Church Street, Santa Maria, CA 93454
===Deanery II (Santa Barbara)=== [[Image:Mission santabarbara chapel.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Mission Santa Barbara]] * [https://holycrosssantabarbara.org/ Holy Cross], 1740 Cliff Drive, Santa Barbara * Our Lady of Guadalupe, 801 Jennings Avenue, Santa Barbara * [http://www.olmc-montecito.com/ Our Lady of Mount Carmel], 1300 East Valley Road, Santa Barbara * [[Our Lady of Sorrows Church (Santa Barbara, California)|Our Lady of Sorrows]], 21 East Sola Street, Santa Barbara * [http://www.parishesonline.com/scripts/HostedSites/Org.asp?ID=17065 San Roque], 325 Argonne Circle, Santa Barbara * [[Mission Santa Barbara|Santa Barbara Mission]], served by the Franciscan Friars, Santa Barbara * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080719133940/http://www.mountcarmelschool.net/stjoe.html St. Joseph], 5048 El Carro Lane, Carpinteria * [http://www.saint-marks.net/ St. Mark (UCSB)], 6550 Picasso Road, Goleta * [http://www.straphaelsb.com/ St. Raphael], 5444 Hollister Avenue, Santa Barbara
===Deanery III (Oxnard, Ventura, Ojai, Fillmore, Santa Paula)=== [[Image:Santa Clara Catholic Church, Oxnard, California.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Santa Clara, Oxnard]] * Mary Star of the Sea, 463 West Pleasant Valley Road, Oxnard * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051027035520/http://www.olgparish-oxnard.org/ Our Lady of Guadalupe], 500 North Juanita Avenue, Oxnard * Our Lady of Guadalupe, 427 North Oak Street, Santa Paula * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080809132658/http://www.olaventura.com/tp40/Default.asp?ID=105411 Our Lady of the Assumption], 3175 Telegraph Road, Ventura * [http://www.sacredheartventura.org/ Sacred Heart], 10800 Henderson Road, Ventura * [[Mission San Buenaventura|San Buenaventura Mission]], Ventura * [http://www.staclara.org/ Santa Clara], 323 South E Street, Oxnard (old chapel at 1333 E Ventura Blvd) * St. Anthony, 2511 S C St, Oxnard * [https://stfrancisfillmore.wordpress.com/ St. Francis of Assisi], 1048 W. Ventura St., Fillmore * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080706174038/http://www.the-tidings.com/2007/032307/sebastianside.htm St. Sebastian], 235 North Ninth Street, Santa Paula * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080905152139/http://www.staconline.org/ St. Thomas Aquinas], 185 St. Thomas Dr., Ojai
===Deanery IV (Simi Valley, Westlake Village, Thousand Oaks, Moorpark, Camarillo)=== [[Image:Father Juniperro Serra Catholic Church, Camarillo.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Juniperro Serra, Camarillo]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080423004736/http://www.padreserra.org/index.php Bl. Janss Road, Thousand Oaks * [http://www.saintpeterclaver.org St. Peter Claver], 5649 E. Pittman St., Simi Valley * [http://www.parishesonline.com/scripts/HostedSites/Org.asp?ID=17080 St. Rose of Lima], 1305 Royal Ave, Simi Valley

{{Infobox Hindu leader | name = H. H. Shri 1008 Shri Satyātma Tīrtha Shrīpādaru | image = Shree_Pic_2014-04-03_01-41.jpg |alt = H. H. Shri 1008 Shri Satyātma Tīrtha Shrīpādaru, 2016 | birth_name = Sarvajñāchārya Guttal | birth_place = [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1973|3|8}} | honors = Abhinava Raghūttama | founder = | order = [[Vedanta]] ([[Uttaradi Matha]]) | guru = [[Satyapramoda Tīrtha|Shri Satyapramoda Tīrtha Swamiji]] | philosophy = [[Dvaita Vedanta]] }} {{DvaitaInfobox}} '''Satyatma Tirtha''' (officially known as {{IAST|Śrī Śrī 1008 Śrī Satyātma-tīrtha Śrīpādaṅgaḷavaru}}; {{lang-kn|ಶ್ರೀ ಶ್ರೀ ೧೦೦೮ ಶ್ರೀ ಸತ್ಯಾತ್ಮತೀರ್ಥ ಶ್ರೀಪಾದಂಗಳವರು}}) is the present pontiff of [[Uttaradi Matha]], a [[matha|math]] (''also'' mutt) dedicated to [[Dvaita]] philosophy, which has a large following in southern [[India]].<ref name=hindu4/><ref name=pune/> He is the 42nd pontiff of [[Uttaradi Matha]] since [[Madhvacharya]], the chief proponent and the one who rejuvenated this [[Dvaita Vedanta|Dvaita philosophy]].
==Early life and education== He was born to Shri Pandit Sudhavisharada Rangāchārya Guttal and K.S. Rukmābāi in Mumbai on 8 March 1973 and named Sarvajñāchārya.<ref name=uttaradi/> Pandit Rangacharya is the ''pūrvāshrama'' (previous to ''sannyāsa'' order) son of Shri Satyapramoda Tīrtha Swamiji.
==Sannyasa== Sarvajñāchārya became a ''[[Sannyasa|sannyasi]]'' at the age of 23, directly from ''[[brahmacharya]]'' at Raghūttama Tīrtha Brundāvana, Tirukoilur (in Tamil Nadu) in the presence of Shri Satyapramoda Tīrtha Swamiji on 24 April 1996<ref name=uttaradi>{{cite web|last=Math|first=Shri Uttaradi|title=Shri Satyatma Tirta|url=http://www.uttaradimath.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=154&Itemid=186|publisher=Shri Uttaradi Math. uttaradimath.org|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref> and was renamed as Satyātma Tīrtha. He is also known as Abhinava Raghūttama Tīrtharu since he received ''sannyasa'' directly from ''[[brahmacharya]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.udupitoday.com/udtoday/news_Udupi-Pontiff-of-Uttaradi-mutt-begins-Chaturmas-today-in-Udupi_422.html|title=Udupi: Pontiff of Uttaradi mutt begins Chaturmas today in Udupi|publisher=Udupi Today Media Network}}</ref> Shri Satyātma Tīrtha Swamiji is the second peethadipati of Uttaradi Math who is a ''[[Brahmacharya|brahmachāri]]''.
==Social responsibility== Shri Satyatma Tirtha, through Uttaradi Math, encouraged water harvesting and management expert, the ''waterman of India'' and [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] winner [[Rajendra Singh]] to give lecture on water conservation and other topics.<ref name=express>{{cite news|last=Express News Service|first=newindianexpress.com|title=Save Arkavathi, Kumudvathi basins, says Rajendra Singh|url=http://newindianexpress.com/cities/bangalore/article588331.ece?service=print|accessdate=5 September 2012|newspaper=The New Indian Express|date=13 August 2012}}</ref> Through Uttaradi Math and jointly with Vishwa Madhva Maha Parishat, he is instrumental in helping needy students every year to the tune of Rs.5.00 lakhs (About US$10,000).<ref name=hindu3/>
===Flood relief=== He has supplied relief materials to flood victims of [[Bellary]], [[Bijapur, Karnataka|Bijapur]], [[Raichur]] and [[Bagalkot]] districts during [[2009 India floods|2009 floods]] and also took measures to construct 100 low cost houses to those who lost houses in the flood.<ref name=hindu3>{{cite news|last=correspondent|first=Staff|title=Math to construct houses for flood affected|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/10/12/stories/2009101252250300.htm|accessdate=5 September 2012|newspaper=The Hindu|date=12 October 2009}}</ref> He has also adopted a rural village in [[Raichur]], [[Karnataka]]<ref name=hindu4/> for integrated development of the village. He is reportedly trying to redefine the role of religious 'math' in modern day society, so that present day 'math' should try to get rid of evils of modern society.<ref name=hindu4/>
==Spiritual discourses== His spiritual discourses (''pravachana'') attract large gatherings, mainly from followers of Madhvacharya and he specialises in talks on Vedic subjects.<ref name=hindu1>{{cite news|last=staff reporter|first=thehindu.com|title=Protect Vedic Dharma, Youth told|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/article2856107.ece|accessdate=5 September 2012|newspaper=The Hindu|date=3 February 2012}}</ref> He has given spiritual discourses at several places like [[Bangalore]],<ref name=hindu2>{{cite news|last=thehindu.com|title=Spiritual Discourse|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/article3736314.ece|accessdate=5 September 2012|newspaper=The Hindu, Bangalore|date=7 August 2012}}</ref> [[Gulbarga]], [[Malkheda]], [[Udupi]], [[Rajahmundry]],<ref name=hindu1/> [[Hyderabad (India)]],<ref name=hindu4>{{cite news|title=For Preservation of Dharma|url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/03/05/stories/2003030500370200.htm|accessdate=5 September 2012|newspaper=The Hindu (Hyderabad)|date=5 March 2003}}</ref> [[Pune]],<ref name=pune>{{cite news|last=Times news network|title=City plays host to Uttaradi pontiff's religious rite|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-09-04/pune/27934919_1_chaturmasya-blood-donation-camps-sankalpa|accessdate=16 September 2012|newspaper=The Times of India (Pune)|date=4 September 2008}}</ref> [[Raichur]],<ref name=hindu4/> [[Dharwad]]<ref name=hindu4/> and [[Chennai]].<ref name=hindu4/> He has also conducted personality development programmes and has written several books on topics like personality development, religion and philosophy.<ref>[http://www.mylib.in/Index.php?search=jagadguru+sri+1008+sri+satyatma+tirtha+swamiji&field=FAuthor MyLib.in: Online Book Library in Bangalore, Corporate Library solutions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Satyatma Tirtha, as the present head of Uttaradi Matha, has also encouraged other authors to write books on religious experiences.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Prasad |first1=PVRK (IAS) |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=When I saw Tirupati Balaji |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C26lbOuDIbYC&pg=PA315&lpg=PA315&dq=satyatma+tirtha&source=bl&ots=VeDatRh6Bd&sig=ddqIfK48aNMgHbSeO6YQ4WjAEI0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=leRZUPLONcjQrQeCt4CYDQ&sqi=2&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=humble%20offering&f=false|format= |accessdate=19 September 2012 |edition=2008 |publisher= |location= |isbn=9788121209335 |page= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Dvaita Vedanta]] * [[Works of Madhvacharya]] * [[Uttaradi Matha]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{notability|date=January 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=January 2018}} {{Sikhism sidebar}}
'''Sikhism in [[Poland]]''' dates back mostly to the 1990s or early 2000s, during the immigration of [[Indian people|Indians]] to Poland. There are about approximately 700 Sikhs in Poland, with the vast majority of them living in the capital of [[Warsaw]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
== Gurdwaras == There is only one [[Gurdwara]] in Poland being stationed in Warsaw. The city's Sikh Gurdwara, called "Gurudwara Singh Sabha",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gurudawara.pl/|title=GURUDWARA SINGH SABHA WARSAW POLAND|website=www.gurudawara.pl|access-date=2017-12-27}}</ref> is the only Sikh shrine in the whole of [[Eastern Europe]] and it is the place where both Sikhs and [[Sindhis]] come together to celebrate [[Baisakhi]].
== Controversy == Sikhs in Poland are generally treated unfavourably by the locals, especially in more rural areas, due to often being mistaken for [[Muslim]]s for their usually darker skin, [[Dastar|turban]] and beard.
One incident in 2015 involved a Sikh man, Navjot Sawhney, who was attacked by a bouncer outside a nightclub in [[Kraków]] because he looked like a "terrorist".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/poland/12029627/Polish-police-tell-British-Sikh-man-what-do-you-expect-after-Paris-attacks-after-nightclub-beating.html|title=Polish police tell British Sikh man 'what do you expect after Paris attacks' after nightclub beating|last=Day|first=Matthew|date=2015-12-02|access-date=2017-12-27|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
== Sources == <references />
[[Category:Sikhism in Europe]] [[Category:Sikhism]] [[Category:Gurdwaras]] [[Category:Religion in Poland]]

{{Infobox newspaper | name = The Jewish Tribune | logo = Jewish-tribune-header.gif | image = | caption = | type = | format = tabloid | owners = Jewish Tribune Inc. | founder = [[B'nai Brith Canada]] | publisher = Michael Mostyn | editor = Norm Gordner | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = Arie Dimant | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = 1964 as ''The Covenant'' | political = Conservative | language = English | ceased publication = January 29, 2015 | headquarters = 15 Hove Street,
North York, Ontario, Canada{{cite journal|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/jewish-tribune/oclc/43631482&referer=brief_results|title=The Jewish tribune.|publisher=|journal=The Jewish tribune.|via=Open WorldCat}} | circulation = 60,490 copies (as of September 2014) }} '''''The Jewish Tribune''''' was a privately owned community-based Canadian weekly Jewish [[newspaper]] founded by and closely associated with [[B'nai Brith Canada]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RvWQgnl80XIC&pg=PA278&dq=%22Jewish+Tribune%22+Canada&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h30kT4u4PMPf0QGK7rCBCQ&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22Jewish%20Tribune%22%20Canada&f=false |title=Transnational identities and practices in Canada |author=Lloyd Lee Wong, Vic Satzewich |publisher=UBC Press |year=2006 |accessdate=January 28, 2012}} It was founded in 1964 as ''The Covenant'', B'nai Brith's in-house newsletter and was later relaunched in the mid-1990s as an external publication under its current name.{{cite news|title=B'nai Brith's Jewish Tribune suspends print edition|url=http://www.cjnews.com/news/israel?q=node/135653|accessdate=February 5, 2015|work=Canadian Jewish News|date=February 2, 2015}} The ''Tribune'' was initially a fortnightly newspaper but became a weekly after several years. At its peak it had a circulation of over 100,000. As of May 2013, ''The Jewish Tribune'' had a circulation of 60,500 copiesThe masthead on their website, as of May 2013. a week which made it, for a time, the largest Jewish weekly publication in Canada. It was distributed in [[Toronto]], [[Montreal]], [[Ottawa]], [[Winnipeg]], [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], and [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], both by regular mail and by the internet and is available for free from newspaper boxes, news stands, businesses, synagogues and various outlets, mostly in Jewish neighbourhoods.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kMgRAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Jewish+Tribune%22+Canada&dq=%22Jewish+Tribune%22+Canada&hl=en&sa=X&ei=mX4kT5bTMumG0QGC5NzJCA&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBTgU |title=From immigration to integration: the Canadian Jewish experience: the Canadian Jewish experience: a millennium edition |author=Ruth Klein, Frank Dimant |publisher= |year=2001 |accessdate=January 28, 2012}} Politically, the newspaper was generally conservative both in Canadian and Israeli politics and may be considered an ideological successor to the ''Jewish Times'', a newspaper published by [[M.J. Nurenberger]] from 1974 to 1992 as a right-wing rival to the more centrist ''[[Canadian Jewish News]]''. Many of the news items it carries documented activities of B'nai Brith Canada and generally reflected the views of the organization while being critical of, first, the [[Canadian Jewish Congress]] and then its successor, the [[Centre for Israel and Jewish Affairs]]. Notable contributors to the newspaper included Mike Cohen, city councilman for Cote Saint Luc and Daniel Smajovits, a well-known Montreal-area writer. M.J.Nurenberger's daughter, Atara Beck, worked as a journalist for the ''Jewish Tribune'' for several years before moving to Israel in 2011, after which she freelanced as the paper's Israel correspondent. ''The Jewish Tribune'''s main competition was the ''[[Canadian Jewish News]]'' (which temporarily ceased publication in 2013). It now also competes with ''Shalom Life'', an English-Hebrew publication aimed at Israeli Canadians in Toronto, and other regional Jewish publications. B'nai Brith Canada president [[Frank Dimant]] was the newspaper's publisher from its inception{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pj1_-1a79kkC&pg=PA152&dq=%22Jewish+Tribune%22+Canada&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h30kT4u4PMPf0QGK7rCBCQ&ved=0CGkQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22Jewish%20Tribune%22%20Canada&f=false |title=No Holiday: 80 Places You Don't Want to Visit |author=Martin Cohen |publisher= |year=2006 |accessdate=January 28, 2012}} until September 2014 when incoming B'nai Brith Canada president Michael Mostyn was appointed publisher. On January 29, 2015, B'nai Brith Canada announced that it was suspending publication of the periodical's print edition for 13 weeks, and possibly permanently. Though the organization claimed it would continue publishing the ''Tribune'' online, one of its columnists announced that staff had been laid off,{{cite tweet|user=mikecohencsl|author=Mike Cohen|number=561236630921437185|date=30 January 2015|title=The Jewish Tribune has ceased publication of its print edition and laid off staff until further notice. B'nai Brith will try & revive it,.}} and its website was not updated after the suspension was announced.{{cite news|title=B’nai Brith Canada’s weekly to suspend print edition|url=http://www.jta.org/2015/01/30/news-opinion/world/bnai-brith-canadas-daily-to-suspend-print-edition#.VMvDiY211Zp.twitter|accessdate=January 30, 2015|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=January 30, 2015}} Subsequently, it has been reported that the newspaper has folded as a cost-cutting move along with the sale of B'nai Brith Canada's headquarters and other facilities.{{cite news|title=B’nai Brith Canada puts headquarters up for sale|url=http://www.jta.org/2015/07/09/news-opinion/israel-middle-east/bnai-brith-canada-puts-headquarters-alzheimers-facility-up-for-sale-2|accessdate=July 10, 2015|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=July 9, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official|http://jewishtribune.ca/ }} *[http://ajpa.org/displaycountry.php?country=CANADA American Jewish Press Association, Canada listings] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=jx1lAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Jewish+Tribune%22+Canada&dq=%22Jewish+Tribune%22+Canada&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8H0kT_rZEOHp0gGG84CCCQ&ved=0CGoQ6AEwCTgK ''A century of the Canadian Jewish press, 1880s-1980s''], Lewis Levendel, Borealis Press, 1989 {{DEFAULTSORT:Jewish Tribune}} [[Category:1964 establishments in Ontario]] [[Category:2015 disestablishments in Ontario]] [[Category:Defunct newspapers of Ontario]] [[Category:Defunct weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Jewish newspapers published in Canada]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Toronto]] [[Category:Publications established in 1964]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 2015]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers published in Ontario]]

The film deals with [[antisemitism]] in France.{{cite news|last1=Liphshiz|first1=Cnaan|title=French Jews react to first screening of buzzy, irreverent comedy on anti-Semitism|url=http://www.jta.org/2016/05/23/arts-entertainment/french-jews-react-to-first-screening-of-buzzy-irreverent-comedy-on-anti-semitism|accessdate=29 May 2016|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=23 May 2016}}http://ukjewishfilm.org/film/the-jews/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/02/opinion/lets-all-become-jews-france-yvan-attal.html ==Cast== *[[Benoît Poelvoorde]] as Boris *[[Valérie Bonneton]] as Eva *[[Dany Boon]] as Pascal *[[Charlotte Gainsbourg]] as Mathilde *[[Grégory Gadebois]] as a Talmudist *[[Denis Podalydès]] as a Talmudist *[[Gilles Lellouche]] as Norbert *[[François Damiens]] as Roger *[[Yvan Attal]] as Yvan ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|5324800}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jews, The}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Films about antisemitism]] [[Category:Films directed by Yvan Attal]] [[Category:Jewish comedy and humor]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French comedy films]] [[Category:2010s comedy films]] [[Category:Antisemitism in France]] [[Category:Films produced by Thomas Langmann]] {{2010s-France-film-stub}} {{2010s-comedy-film-stub}}

{{no footnotes|date=October 2010}} [[File:Yediyuru siddhalingeshwara swamy trmple 01.jpg|thumb|right|Yediyur Siddhalingeshwara Swamy Temple]] '''Yediyuru Siddhalingeshwara Temple''' is a very famous pilgrimage centre situated in [[Yedeyuru]] Village, [[Kunigal]] Town of [[Karnataka]] State in India.
Though called as a temple, it contains Nirvikalpa Shivayoga Samadhi of Tontada Siddalinga, a Great revered Lingayata Saint who flourished during the end of 15th century.
The temple holds annual festivals during [[Maha Shivaratri]] and [[Ugadi]].
On the 7th Day of the commencement of the Hindu calendar (Ugadi)Chaitra bahula saptami, jathre is performed to mark the attaining of the Samadhi of Sri Siddhalingeshwara. Every year on Maha Shivarathri Sahasra Rudrabhisheka is performed. The Sahasra Kamala Pooja, Laksha Bilvarchane pooje is performed in the month of Shravana and Kumbhabhisheka is performed on each new moon day. During the annual festival of Deepavali (festival of lights) Laksha Deepotsava is performed by illuminating the temple with oil lamps as per Hindu tradition. The temple has a large wooden Chariot (Ratha). The car festival is held on the 7th lunar day of the bright fortnight of Chaitra Masa (March–April).
== About Sri Siddhalingeshwara Swamy == Sri [[Siddalingeshwara]] Swamy a great revered Sharana Saint in the path of Lingayatha Shiva Sharana Parampare of diffusion of Thatva of Life called VACHANAS. He travelled far and wide preaching Sharana faith which is predominantly praying with ISHTA LINGA (atma linga) as envisaged by Basavanna, Allamaprabhu and a vast group of learned men and women from all walks of life (12th century in present-day Bijapur district).
He performed 12 years of penance at a garden belongs to Vokkaligara Nambiyana (Thota) and hence came to be known as Thontada Siddalingeshwara Swamy. He headed the Murugi Mutha and had a large following of disciples some of who wrote on Lingayat faith and philosophy. Hence Yedeyuru is deemed to be a seat of awakened spiritual consciousness.
He has written Shathsthala Jnana Saramrutha, containing 701 [[Vachana]]s (Poems) which are directing Sthalas (route) to Attain Ikya i.e. involvement to light.
He travelled far and wide, preached eternal truth and performed many miracles for scores of people irrespective of their caste or creed. His life and values held by him demonstrated the divine powers attained by him to heal the sick and suffering.
He is regarded as one of the greatest Saints of the Sharana Sect in the Lingayat religion.
The temple contact number is 08132228224
